Note:
The music that accompanies all but one of the witnesses is by Robert Fayrfax. See Ringler Jr. (1992)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler , TM 1452.
Subjects: Rivers, Earl, Anthony Woodville, Lord Scales and second Earl Rivers; Woodville, Anthony, Lord Scales and second Earl Rivers
Bibliographic Ghosts: London, British Library Cotton Vespasian A.XII: not in this MSS.
_description: Earl Rivers, written while imprisoned at Pontrefact — five 8-line stanzas

CamFitzMus.Transcription:
Somewhat musing and more mourningin remembryng þe vnstedfastnes
                    þis world beyngof such walyng[ ]rue contraryyngwhat may I gese I
                    feyr dowteles[ ]hope to fynd a specyall remedylet it ouerpass and
                    thynk þeron no more
CamFitzMus.Note:
Fragment, preceded by end of another stanza or song, ‘chaunce
                    wyllyng to dye with verte & vide’; with musical notation. Fallows (1993)
XFallows,  David. 
             “The Drexel Fragments of Early Tudor Song.” 
             Royal Musical Association Research Chronicle
         No. 26 (1993): 5-18. observes that Cambridge UK,  Fitzwilliam Museum Mus 1005, Wells,  Wells Cathedral Library Music MSS, Fayrfax frag., and New York,  New York Public Library Drexel Fragments 4185 all derive from the same
                    manuscript.

BLAdd31922.First Lines: SVmwhat musyngin remembryngthunstedfastnesseþis world beyngof such walyng…
BLAdd31922.Last Lines: …my lyf was lentit is ny spentwelcum fortune but she is mentsuch ys her wont
BLAdd31922.Note: Words and notation repeated for three voices.
